Author: hussong
Content:
The original article contains a few more arguments: http://www.thestandard.com/news/2008/02/28/communications-wh...

The comments at slashdot point out the underlying economic trade-off: cost of reliability vs. cost of downtime.

Author: marcus
Content:
The point is that because of the lower funding they have a lot more exit options than an average VC backed company and can exit in a lower valuation where an IPO doesn't make sense.

Of course some of your companies have awesome potential ( I wouldn't have applied if I didn't believe in the model) but they have a lower incentive to wait for an IPO than a VC backed company.

Author: brianlash
Content:
Thanks for the feedback Tim. I replied on the blog (and posted an update for those who don't read the comments), but here's my take for the YC community:

I think you're right... by virtue of the interface/function issue, Twitter isn't an example of ubiquitous computing per se. But I do think it's an important milestone on the path there.

As I said, you're more "expert" than me. Thanks for adding your opinion.

Author: brianlash
Content:
Great anecdote of Twitter in action. I was around to watch that whole thing unfold for Quotably. It was neat to see a conversation which began here gain so much traction so fast.

How exciting for those guys...

Author: jeroen
Content: Does it even make a difference? The whole world is using gmail as if it weren't in beta, with expectations to match.
